originalTitle: Why a beauty spot in South Africa could be about to run out of water
title: Why a beauty spot in South Africa could be about to run out of water
content: Official estimates suggest that around 55% of the town's drinkable water is lost to leaking pipes.

originalTitle: Saif al-Islam Gaddafi, son of ex-Libyan leader, reportedly shot dead
title: Sad News from Our African Family in Libya
content:
Hello, Amazing African Friends!

Hello, my wonderful friends! Your kid-friendly news reporter from Africa is here. I have some news to share with you today from a country not too far away, called Libya. Libya is a very special country, just like all the countries in Africa. Today, we are talking about a grown-up man named Saif al-Islam. He was the son of a very important leader who used to lead Libya a long time ago. It's a bit of sad news that we hear from the grown-up newspapers and TV channels.

Where is Libya?

Libya is a beautiful country in North Africa. It has big, sandy deserts and also a long coastline next to the blue sea. Many friendly people live there. It's a land of sunshine and ancient stories. Did you know? Libya is home to a part of the Sahara Desert, which is the biggest hot desert in the world! Imagine riding a camel there!

Who is Saif al-Islam?

Saif al-Islam was a grown-up man, 53 years old. That's older than most of your parents! He was the son of a man named Muammar Gaddafi, who was the leader of Libya for a very, very long time. Think of a leader like the head of your school, but for a whole country! Sometimes, the children of leaders also become important people in their country, helping to make big decisions. Saif al-Islam was one of those people. He was once seen as one of the most powerful people in Libya, helping his father lead the country.

What Happened?

We heard some sad news from the grown-up news channels in Libya. They are saying that Saif al-Islam has passed away. The news says he was shot. This means his life ended. When we say "reportedly," it means that people are sharing this news, but sometimes it takes a little while for everyone to be completely sure. It's like when your friend tells you something, but you haven't seen it with your own eyes yet. It happened on Tuesday. This is a very serious and sad event for many people, especially for his family and those who knew him in Libya.

What Does "Powerful" Mean?

When we say Saif al-Islam was once a "powerful" person, it means he had a lot of influence. He could help make important rules and plans for the country and its people. Leaders and powerful people help guide their country, like a captain guides a ship. Sometimes, leaders try to make their country better and stronger. They make sure people have schools, hospitals, and safe places to live. It's a big job to look after an entire country! Did you know? Libya's capital city is called Tripoli. It's a big city with lots of people and buildings, just like other big cities you might know in Africa.

Countries and Changes

All countries, including Libya, sometimes go through big changes. Sometimes, leaders change, or new rules are made. These changes can be calm and peaceful, or sometimes they can be a bit difficult. When a country goes through big changes, it can affect many people. It's important for everyone to be safe and happy, no matter what changes are happening. Did you know? Libya is known for its amazing ancient Roman ruins, like Leptis Magna. These are very old buildings and cities that tell us stories from a long, long time ago!

Why is This News Important?

We share this news because Saif al-Islam was a very well-known person in Libya and around Africa. When important people are in the news, it helps us understand what is happening in different parts of our big, beautiful continent. It also reminds us that countries sometimes have tough times. Things don't always go smoothly, and sometimes there are problems. But even during tough times, people always hope for peace and safety for everyone. Did you know? The national animal of Libya is the Barbary lion, even though it's now very rare. It's a symbol of strength!

Wishing for Peace in Libya

Even though this is sad news, we always wish for peace and happiness for all the children and grown-ups in Libya. We hope that everyone there can live safely, go to school, play with their friends, and have enough food to eat. News reporters like me help share stories from all over Africa, so we can all learn and understand more about our continent and our neighbours. Let's send our kind thoughts to the people of Libya and hope for bright and peaceful days ahead for them. Thank you for listening, my friends! Stay curious and keep learning about our amazing world!

originalTitle: Somali woman executed for murdering a child in a case that sparked outrage
title: Somali woman executed for murdering a child in a case that sparked outrage
content: Hodan Mohamud Diiriye faced a firing squad after being found guilty of beating Saabirin Saylaan to death.

title: ‘A great honor’: Key takeaways from Trump’s meeting with Colombia’s Petro
content: Despite months of clashing over US military attacks and drug trafficking, the two leaders shared a 'terrific' meeting.

title: Thousands of Epstein documents taken down after victims identified

originalTitle: US says it shot down Iranian drone flying towards aircraft carrier
title: US says it shot down Iranian drone flying towards aircraft carrier
content: A US military spokesman says the drone was shot down while approaching an American vessel in the Arabian Sea.

originalTitle: Saif al-Islam Gaddafi, son of ex-Libyan leader, reportedly shot dead
title: Saif al-Islam Gaddafi, son of ex-Libyan leader, reportedly shot dead
content: The 53-year-old, who was once widely seen as the second most powerful person in Libya, was killed on Tuesday according to Libyan media.

originalTitle: 'Years in the making' - are Arsenal ready to shed 'nearly-men' tag?
title: 'Years in the making' - are Arsenal ready to shed 'nearly-men' tag?
content: Arsenal have moved a step closer to winning their first major silverware since 2020 by beating Chelsea 4-2 on aggregate in the Carabao Cup semi-final.

originalTitle: 'It hurts me' - Guardiola vows to speak up on conflicts
title: 'It hurts me' - Guardiola vows to speak up on conflicts
content: Pep Guardiola has spoken passionately about children being killed and injured in conflict zones across the world, saying the footage he sees "hurts me".

originalTitle: Chelsea adopt Match of the Day tactic to stop Arsenal set-piece threat
title: Chelsea adopt Match of the Day tactic to stop Arsenal set-piece threat
content: Despite losing their Carabao Cup semi-final, Chelsea attempted a new way of stopping Arsenal set-pieces - just days after a similar suggestion on Match of the Day.
